title: Infrared radiation and subsequent hot-air drying increased lipid concomitant contents and improved storage stability of fresh camellia seeds.
abstract: Camellia oleifera is a woody oil-bearing crop, and the quality of its seeds and pressed oil is affected by the postharvest drying. In order to find a suitable drying method for camellia seeds maintaining their good qualities, effects of three drying methods, including room temperature (RT) drying, 60 °C hot-air (HA) drying, as well as 600-800 W infrared pre-drying and sequential 60 °C hot-air (IR-HA) drying, on the drying efficiency, qualities and storage stabilities of camellia seeds were compared.
journal: Journal of the science of food and agriculture
